1. Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Action Response Policies:



We at FreshPoint Southern California are committed to employee, public, and environmental safety. This commitment is demonstrated by our comprehensive accidental release prevention program that covers areas such as the design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training associated with the process at our facility. It is our policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of regulated substance, ammonia. Unforeseeable, if such a release does occur, our highly trained employees are on hand to coordinate with professional emergency responders and the facility's professional refrigeration service firm.



The emergency action plan provides the response organization with notification procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures which will be implemented to effectively respond to emergency situations that may arise at the facility





2. The Stationary Source and the Regulated Substances Handled:



The primary business of FreshPoint Southern California is the storage and distribution of refrigerated food products. The facility is approximately 1.7 miles east of Interstate 605, approximately 1.9 miles north of Highway 60, and approximately 1.9 miles south of Interstate 10.  We maintain one regulated substance present at our facility. This substance is Ammonia (anhydrous). The maximum inventory of Ammonia (anhydrous) that is expected to be present in this facility, based on process/operational requirements, is approximately 10,700 pounds.  The ammonia refrigeration system is a closed-loop system that cycles the refrigerant from liquid to gas and back again. There are no expected discharges or emissions of ammonia associated with the refrigeration system. 





3. The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and the Chemical Specific Prevention Steps:



Our facility has taken the following steps as required b

y 40 CFR Part 68 of the EPA. Our Ammonia (anhydrous) process is subject to the Cal-OSHA PSM Standard under CCR Title 8, Section 5189. Our facility is also subject to EPCRA Section 302 reporting requirements. The following sections briefly describe the elements of the release prevention program that is in place at our facility.



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTIONA PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS:



In order to operate the ammonia refrigeration system, the facility complies with the California Occupational Safety and Health Administration (CaIOSHA), Process Safety Management (PSM) standard (Section 5189 of Title 8, CCR), the EPA Risk Management Program (RMP), and the California Office of Emergency Services (Cal OES) California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program. 



Administrative Measures:

 

The facility operates in accordance with the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration (IIAR) guidelines and standards.

The FreshPoint Southern California ammonia refrigeration system has many safety features. Much of the safety of the system is inherent in the policies and procedures that govern the operation of the system. For example, FreshPoint Southern California operates in accordance with the California Accidental Release Prevention (CaIARP) Program, CalOSHA PSM Program, and EPA RMP Program. 



Process Safety Information:



The facility, including the ammonia system, was designed and constructed in accordance with the Uniform Mechanical Code for the safe operation of the ammonia refrigeration system. These safety features include an Ammonia Dispersion Tank and ammonia sensors near the evaporators and inside the Engine Room. The compressors are equipped with safety mechanisms that will cause the units to shut down if operating conditions exceed designated safety limits. Also, level indicators, alarms, and switches are installed in key points within the system to monitor the supply of liquid ammonia and to ensure that a vessel is not over

filled. Pressure relief valves on all pressure vessels protect the equipment from over pressurization and are commonly piped to the Ammonia Dispersion Tank. 



FreshPoint Southern California has also developed a preventive maintenance program that utilizes the services of a professional refrigeration contractor to complete regularly scheduled inspections, tests as well as repairs to the system as needed.



Operating Procedures:



FreshPoint Southern California maintains written operating procedures. These procedures address various modes of operation such as initial start-up, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown, and start-up after a turnaround. The information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to operators involved in the process.



Training:



FreshPoint Southern California has a comprehensive training program in place to ensure that employees who are operating processes are competent in the operating procedures associated with these processes. New employees receive basic classroom training in process operations, followed by on-the-job supervision until they are deemed competent to work independently. Refresher training is provided at least annually and more frequently as needed.



Mechanical Integrity:



FreshPoint Southern California carries out highly documented maintenance checks on process equipment to ensure proper operation. Process equipment examined by these checks includes pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping system, relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, controls and pumps. Qualified personnel carry out maintenance operations with special training in maintenance practices. Furthermore, these personnel are given specialized training as needed. Any equipment deficiencies identified by the maintenance checks are corrected in a timely manner.



Management of Change:



Written procedures are in place at FreshPoint Southern California to manage change in proc

ess chemicals, technology, equipment and processes. Process operators, maintenance personnel, or any other employees whose job tasks are affected by a modification in process operations, are promptly made aware of, and given, training to deal with the modifications.



Pre-Startup Reviews:



Pre-startup reviews related to new processes, and to modifications in established processes are conducted as a regular practice at FreshPoint Southern California. These reviews are conducted to confirm that construction, equipment, operating and maintenance procedures are suitable for safe start-up prior to placing equipment into operation.



Compliance Audits:



FreshPoint Southern California conducts audits on a regular basis to determine whether the provisions set out under the RMP Rule are being implemented. These audits are carried out at least every three years and any corrective actions required as a result of the audits are undertaken in a safe and timely manner.



Incident Investigation:



FreshPoint Southern California promptly investigates any incident that has resulted in, or could reasonably result in a catastrophic release of a regulated substance. These investigations are undertaken to identify the situation leading to the incident, as well as any corrective actions to prevent the release from recurring. All reports are retained for a minimum of 5 years.



Employee Participation:



FreshPoint Southern California believes that process safety management and accident prevention are a team effort. Company employees are strongly urged to express their views concerning accident prevention issues and to recommend improvements. In addition, our employees have access to all information created as part of the facility's implementation of the RMP rule, including information resulting from process hazard analysis, in particular.



Contractors:



On occasion, FreshPoint Southern California hires contractors to conduct specialized maintenance and construction activitie

s. Prior to selecting a contractor, a thorough evaluation of the contractor's safety performance is completed. FreshPoint Southern California has a strict policy of informing contractors of known potential hazards related to the contractor's

work and the process. Contractors are also informed of all the procedures for emergency notification and evacuation, should an accidental release of a regulated substance occur.





4. 5-Year Accident History:



EPA's RMPdefines "accident" as the following:



"The release must be from a covered process and involve a regulated substance above its threshold quantity process.



The release must have caused at least one of the following:



? On-site death, injuries, or significant property damage (40 CFR 68.42(a)); or

? Known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place (40 CFR 68.42(a))."



Based on the above definition and an investigation into the facility's accident history conducted during the PHA Revalidation meeting on January 25, 2017, there have been no significant releases of ammonia that exceeded the Federal Reportable Quantity of 100 pounds or the state requirement mandating immediate reporting of any release or threatened release of a hazardous material in the past five years.  In addition, there have been no injuries resulting from an ammonia release, nor any releases or "near misses" that warranted an internal incident investigation.





5. Emergency Action Plan:



FreshPoint Southern California is included in the written community emergency response plan. This facility has its own emergency action plan. The emergency action plan includes specific actions to be taken in action to accidental releases of regulated substances. The emergency action plan includes procedures for informing the public and local response agencies of a chemical release and information on emergency health care.



Facility personnel receive annual training on emergency procedures.

FreshPoint Southern California uses the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) Incident Command System (ICS).



The local agency coordinating the facility emergency action plan is the Los Angeles Fire Department Station 87 (City of Industry), which has the phone number: 626-336-2611.





6. Planned Changes to Improve Safety:



Several developments and findings have resulted from the implementation of the various elements of our accidental release prevention program. These include the following:

1. Continue our annual facility evacuation drills and planning.

2. Continue employee training and involvement through safety team participation.

3. Continue internal and external safety audits/inspections and implement changes as needed.

4. Continue to maintain a high level of service and repair for every piece of ammonia refrigeration equipment, by utilizing in-house visual inspections plus the services of expert refrigeration contractors.
